handNotes.handNote: Red crayon or thick red pencil. Probably a different hand from Mitford's that marks many of her letters, sometimes drawing diagonal lines across pages, and sometimes writing words overtop and perpendicularly across Mitford's writing. A red line is drawn from top left to bottom right of each of the first five leaves as well as leaves seven through nine. On leave six and ten, a red line is drawn from top left to bottom right across each of the text blocks. There is no red crayon across the address text block.

Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them, who left grey pencil marks and numbered her letters now in the Reading Central Library's collection. This letter is numbered "2" in the top left of the first leaf. Also numbered 1820 on the top of the fifth leaf.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p: I have just this moment received your most kind & entertaining letter, my dear friend, & I hasten to answer it on the full gallop that I may catch our flying M.P. Mr Fyshe Palmer--who was in Reading yesterday & our (Deuce take that blot--more haste worse speed!) our moveable Member who was in Reading yesterday & therefore will not be there tomorrow. First let me express how unfeignedly sorry I am--we are--for the sickness you have had to encounter at Bickham--I hope this will find your daughterElford had two daughters; it is unclear to which she refers. recovering both her strength & her looks--& that your cough will disappear in this mild weather--melt & go off like the snow. Mama & I have kept quite well this unhealthy winter--Papa has not--he has had a great deal of head achheadache & heavy cold--& as he takes no manner of care of himself--comes down from London at four oclocko'clock in the morning on the outside of a coach--& other tendencies of the same nature (I hope he is looking over my shoulder) can scarcely expect to be free from complaint. Mrs. Dickinson is not yet confined & keeps pretty well as to health though a good deal troubled with superstitious forebodings which I do all in my power to drive out of her head by gayer nonsense. Now you have our bulletin all round.

What you say of Ivanhoe is admirably just and true--Rowena is a mere woman of straw--a peg to hang love upon--as almost all his heroines are--of that horrible old woman I had before made dishonourable mention--& those two scenes of burning & of torture are quite unworthy of so great a Poet--He picked up that love of representing bodily suffering though, where
he got many a better thing, among the old Dramatists--they are sad bloody people those Websters & Marlowes & Fords & Massingers! And he sacrifices every thing to strong impression--as you well know--but it is terribly disgusting--& the worst of it is that even his bad purpose is not answered--one is shocked for a moment & then one comforts oneself with reflecting that it is all a fiction & takes up the book with diminished interest.--The reality of bodily suffering is necessary to produce that wonderful & mysterious horror which some descriptions of torture excite--I remember being ill for a whole fortnight from reading the account of Ravaillac's execution--which concludes the Memoires de Sully--& I rarely take up that delightful book even now without some sense of that shuddering feeling--a passage in Mr. Evelyn's Diary produced nearly the same effect on my too irritable nerves--but then it was the truth of those scenes--the knowledge--the certainty that they had occured which fixed & deepened the impression. Have not you this feeling?--After all IvanhoeIvanhoe is a glorious book! How exceedingly fine is the scene where Rebecca described to the sick Ivanhoe the process of storming the Castle! How minute & honest & true the circumstance of her being covered with a shield!--All other romances would have gloried in exposing her without defence--& made her escape the darts by an unnatural miracle--that scene is in the very spirit of the old Dramatists--another source of fine Poetry whih he has studied with equal success is the --Jeanie Deans--& Rebecca both owe their eloquence to fine Orientalism of their language--& their pure & noble cast of character is probably derived from the same source.--By the bye are you quite sure that the Great Unknown is Mr. Walter Scott? Do you quite disbelieve that there is a partner in the firm--by no means a sleeping partner
in short, are you quite incredulous as to the American brother? Mr. Scott, however, (for in that name we both agree), is least my dear Friend as yet unimitated & he tell you the truth.--I almost think him inimitable--he has all the faults that you ascribe to him & a great many more--but there is a perpetual power of inventing new characters--a life--an individuality--a creativeness in his genius which is only to be met with in the great poets--Homer--Ariosto--Chaucer--Shakespeare. He must be thought of as a Poet--Other Novelists delightful as they are take their seats on the prose bench of Authorship--Nobody would ever be tempted to call Patronage a Poem--& by the way I do not, much as I admire her., class Miss Edgeworth with Miss Austen--the inimitable lamented Miss Austen! Miss Edgeworth's books have a Do-me-good air about them which takes away their freedom--a wildness of plot which will not let one believe in their reality--& she deals too much in the factitious part of life and manners of fashionable people--so that her work will in course of time get out of date like an old head dress--a misfortune whch cannot happen to the poetical antiquity of Mr. Scott, or the unchangeable common life of Miss Austen.-- When I wrote to you last I think I had just begun Petrarque et Laure--Don't read it.--I believe I confided to you that I was a great admirer of that famous Lover--but still one must respect him as a great restorer of learning & one of the founders of his sweet language--Now Madame de Genlis has made up from Petrarch a sort of male Corinne--a lute-playing Improvisatore who goes about haranguing & declaiming in verse & in prose! Now nobody can ever have read one of Petrarch's sonnets without being certain that by no possible charge could one line of them be extempore--they seem painfully written word
by word syllable by syllable--It is their fault, that they are of all Poems the most recherchés--Moreover Madame de Genlis makes Petrarque out an Angel & then says she is just like him! Really these French women are vain of their own vanity! Do you ever read Miss Burney's novels? I mean the lesser Burney--not Madame d'Arblay but her Sister whom I like better. We are reading one now--Country Neighbours--pretty enough I think--Faulty by millions--a heroine who is so young so wise so good so beautiful & so accomplished that she makes one sick even before she saves her lover's life, an iniquity so Miss-Porterish that I quite wonder at Miss Burney's lighting upon it--the plot too is exceedingly disagreeable & entangled--all in a Snarl as Cotton-spinners say, & mighty difficult to undo. But eventually the book is pretty--there is some good observation in it--& a sarcastic old lady whom I like exceedingly--to say nothing of a most amiable old Maid.--Well I think I have talked enough of Novels--Did you ever read a little book which has been lately reprinted The Captivity of Captain John Knox in the Island of Ceylon? It is charming--If one did not know it to be nothing but a real true history told by the very man to whom it happened one should take it for one of the enchanting fictions of Defoe. Nothing but Robinson Crusoe was ever so vividly real.

I thought I had done with books--but I find I have not--Ben Jonson's Sad Shepherd is a fragment of a Pastoral Drama said to have been left unfinished in consequence of his friend Fletcher's exquisite Faithful Shepherdess--only two acts & a scene remain, but they are enchanting--Not in Old Ben's common Dramatic Style, so stiff & artifical--but in the sweet & tender manner of some of his beautiful lyrics. If finished it would have been one of the finest things in the language--the story relates to Robin Hood--Gammer Gurton's
NeedleGammer Gurton's Needle is quite another matter--You know that it is the oldest English Play--& really it is one of the most diverting--Coarse enough to be sure but exceedingly fresh & frolicsome & funny & not at all unintelligible--Miss James who is by farone of the most elegant person of my acquaintance says she likes it better than any Comedy in the language--One of the characters in it always put me in mind of Edie Ochiltree--not in his supernatural capacity----but in his better vocation of a merry old beggar--The "Antiquary" after all is my favorite of the whole set of Scotch novels--it is written with more verve--is more a pure exertion of Intellect--seems to be the favorite of the Author--& above all is the least popular among the novel reading young Misses who praise is not fame. There are more faults than in any--including Old Elspeth & all the story--as well as that incredible Dousterwivel-- still it is my favorite--Tell me is it your'syours?

You are very good to the Bishop of Salisbury to assign his "distractions" as a reason for his thefts--or an excuse--but did you never observe that your absent people sometimes make very good use of their absences? I had a friend--an old Portuguese Countess who came here when the rest of theher tribe went to the Brazils--she could not bear to be beaten at Chess--& being like the Bishop very absent, always when she saw the game going against her used to stare about a little--sweep the men off the board and get up with a "Finisons!--J'ai de distractions!" I never knew her to have "distraction" when she was winning in my life--And some such useful fit of absence seized the Right Revd. when he forgot to return poor Mr. Dickinson's and Rembrandts--How you love to laugh at my pedantry!--Well I do think the elements are in me & that if I knew any thing at all I really should be a Pedant.
But I was full of those fine etchings when I talkedwrote to you & could not help talking of them--Weinotter's are chiefly little tiny landscapes on slips of paper--abundantly sweet & delicate & graceful--& Mr. Dickinson says rare.

I have just heard that the King is dead--Poor venerable old Man!--It is fortunate for you that my paper is nearly filled & the servant waiting to take my letter into Reading or I should have vented to you, my ever kindest & most indulgent friend, some of that fullness of thought & feeling which such an event forces into every mind!
Adieu! Pray write soon--& give us a good account of you all--My Father and Mother join in kindest compliments, & I am always, my dear Sir William
div.closer:
Most sincerely & affectionately your'syours
M.R. Mitford.

postscript.p: Pray forgive my blobs and blunders

Feby 2nd--Have you read Spence's Anecotes? I have just finished them--a delightful chitchat book after the manner of Boswell, Pope being the hero. I never saw Pope to such advantage--nor Bolingbroke--Addison cuts a very shabby figure indeed--How very out-of-fashion the critical remarks seem now! a list of English Prose writers & neither Jeremy Taylor nor Isaac Walton, nor Sir Thomas Brown so much as hinted at!--Observations on English Poets & Lord Dorset & Rochester & the two Dukes of Buckingham examined & sifted & talked about as if they were worth finding fault with!--What a famous text book this of Spence's will be for one of Mr. Dickinson's long lectures! How he will glory in these opinions positive & negative these omissions & commisionscommissions! How he will buffet me with Mr. Spence & knock me down with Mr. Pope! Excellent sport for him!--& no very bad fun for me.--no baby there yet.--I wonder very much when I shall get a frank--If I don't get one soon my letter will be too heavy--Do you know this calamity did actually befall me once with Miss James--I waited for a cover, & wrote on & on,--till I filled four sheets and was forced to send them by the Coach. Good bye my dear Friend. I have at last pulled the wax off to lighten my packet--for the half dozenth time Adieu dear Friend.
